heading.title: PART 7 PARTIES TO PROCEEDINGS AND REPRESENTATION [rr 7.1–7.42]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 7 PARTIES TO PROCEEDINGS AND REPRESENTATION [rr 7.1–7.42]

p.text: In this Division, person under legal incapacity includes a person who is incapable of managing his or her affairs.
Legislation cited in [7.13.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 3.
(NSW) Mental Health Act 2007.
(NSW) NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 s 3.

This term is defined in CPA s 3 . Its principal meaning is “person who is under a legal incapacity in relation to the conduct of legal proceedings”. The expression includes minors, protected persons, patients under the Mental Health Act 2007 and persons who are unable to communicate their intentions because of a physical or mental disability. The meaning of the expression “incapable of managing his or her affairs” for the purposes of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 is discussed in Re GHI (a protected person) (2005) 221 ALR 589; [2005] NSWSC 581; BC200504621 at [4]–[21] .

The amplitude of the CPA s 3 definition makes it difficult to determine what, if any, additional element of incapacity is intended to be captured by the inclusive definition in the present rule — that the person is incapable of managing their affairs: Doulaveras v Daher (2009) 253 ALR 627; [2009] NSWCA 58; BC200901704 at [155]–[159] . It may be that the rule is intended to highlight the need to be satisfied of the particular person’s capacity in relation to specific tasks relevant to the litigation, rather than their general or overall capacity to manage their affairs: Azar v Kathirgamalingan [2012] NSWCA 429; BC201210040 at [168] — citing Guthrie v Spence (2009) 78 NSWLR 225; [2009] NSWCA 369; BC200910295 at [174]–[175] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.14] r 7.14 Proceedings to be commenced or carried on by tutor (cf SCR Part 63, rules 2 and 3(2); DCR Part 45, rules 2 and 3; LCR Part 34, rules 3 and 4)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings to be commenced or carried on by tutor (cf SCR Part 63, rules 2 and 3(2); DCR Part 45, rules 2 and 3; LCR Part 34, rules 3 and 4)

p.text: A person under legal incapacity may not commence or carry on proceedings except by his or her tutor.
Unless the court orders otherwise, the tutor of a person under legal incapacity may not commence or carry on proceedings except by a solicitor.
Legislation cited in [7.14.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Powers of Attorney Act 2003 s 21.

The ordinary rule is that an incapable person can only conduct proceedings by a tutor or guardian: Rudeforth v Crawford [1926] VLR 303 . This general rule applies unless there is some contrary statutory or procedural rule: Myers v Nominal Defendant [1966] 1 NSWR 659 . It applies even if the incapable person has previously appointed an attorney under s 21 of the Powers of Attorney Act 2003: Steinecke (bht Gardos) v Wayne [2011] NSWSC 428; BC201103356 at [2]–[5].

There is some controversy as to whether this limitation (in the case of a minor) is procedural only and does not affect either the incapable person’s substantive entitlement or substantive liability: Haines v Leves (1987) 8 NSWLR 442 at 449 (complaint of sex discrimination made by a minor); Ex parte Davis (1901) 1 SR (NSW) 187 ; Darke v Eltherington [1963] Qd R 375 (limitation period running against an infant); Halsbury’s Laws of England, 4th ed, Vol 24, paras [895.1] and [896.1]; cf Wettig v Langdon (1885) 11 VLR 530 ; Myers v Nominal Defendant [1966] 1 NSWR 659 at 667 . A failure to sue through a tutor can be regarded as a mere irregularity which can be waived by the defendant: Ex parte Brocklebank (1877) 6 Ch D 358 ; Mewburn v Mewburn (1934) 51 WN (NSW) 170 ; Darke v Eltherington [1963] Qd R 375 ; Spellson v George (1987) 11 NSWLR 300 at 313. Alternatively, leave to amend may be given to add a tutor: Flight v Bolland (1828) 4 Russ 298 ; Paroczy v Cook [1971] 2 SASR 14.

It has been said that the real object of appointing a tutor is to ensure that the conduct of the litigation is under the control of a responsible person, and to secure a successful defendant’s costs: Ex parte Davis (1901) 1 SR (NSW) 187 at 189 ; South v Northern Sydney Area Health Service [2003] NSWSC 479; BC200302911 . Accordingly, if an incapable person sues without a tutor, the defendant may apply to set aside the originating process and the solicitors who issued it may be ordered to pay costs: Geilinger v Gibbs [1897] 1 Ch 479 ; Fernee v Gorlitz [1915] 1 Ch 177 ; Sartori v Macleod (1897) 22 VLR 498 .

If the action is commenced by a tutor, a defendant cannot plead a defence disputing the disability of the incapable person or the tutor’s authority. The proper course is to bring a summary application for the stay or dismissal of the proceedings: Richmond v Branson [1914] 1 Ch 968 (disputed mental capacity); Russian Commercial and Industrial Bank v Comptoir d’escompte de Mulhouse [1925] AC 112 (dispute about agent’s authority to bring proceedings). An enquiry may be directed to determine whether the proceedings are for the benefit of the incapable person: Percival v Cross (1882) 7 PD 234; Wallace v Wallace (1899) 24 VLR 859; McLaughlin v Moore (1884) 5 LR (NSW) Eq 111; Muir v Harper (1900) 25 VLR 534 ; whether they have been properly brought: Huxley v Wootton (1912) 29 TLR 132 ; and whether the tutor is a proper person to conduct the proceedings: Towsey v Groves (1863) 32 LJ Ch 225; Muir v Harper, above. If the court is satisfied that the proceedings have not been properly brought, the court may stay the proceedings and order the tutor to pay the costs: Huxley v Wootton, above.
Legislation cited in [7.14.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.12, r 7.16.

An action against an incapable person should be commenced in the ordinary way. Service must be made in accordance with r 10.12 of the UCPR. It is not necessary to describe the defendant as an incapable person in the originating process or to join the tutor. However, an incapable person cannot enter an appearance except by their tutor. (But see Surrey Insurance Co Ltd v Nagy [1968] SASR 437 .) Before the tutor can take any step in the proceedings, the consent required by r 7.16 of the UCPR must be filed.

Either the person concerned, or an opposing party, may raise the issue of the person’s capacity opposing party or the person concerned may raise the issue of capacity for determination by the court: see [7.4.10] and Murray v Williams [2010] NSWSC 1243; BC201008009 . In some instances of incapacity, particularly where it is involves some forms of mental illness; a person’s capacity may fluctuate. If there is a significant risk that a person will be incapacitated during the course of the conduct of the proceedings, the court will appoint a tutor for the whole of the litigation: see the Hon Justice PLG Brereton “Acting for the Incapable — A Delicate Balance” (2012) 35 Australian Bar Review 244 at 246–247. If a person’s legal incapacity comes to an end, the tutor cannot continue to conduct the proceedings: Brown v Weatherhead (1844) 4 Hare 122; 67 ER 586 . (In the absence of clear evidence of the cessation of disability, the court may allow the proceedings to continue with the appointed tutor: Almack v Moore (1878) 2 LR Ir 90 at 93–4.) Where disability has ceased, the tutor should give notice to the court and the opposing party. No form is prescribed, but the notice of cessation of disability should clearly state the reason for the cessation of disability, such as “The plaintiff has come of full age since the start of the proceedings”: Schmidt v Winn [1933] QWN 38 ; Feeney v Pieper [1964] QWN 23 ; Carberry v Davies [1968] 2 All ER 817 . The formerly incapable person may elect to go on with the proceedings: Brown v Weatherhead (1844) 4 Hare 122; 67 ER 586 . That election is made by doing anything that could reasonably be considered an adoption of the proceedings: Baile v Baile (1872) LR 13 Eq 497 at 508. Once the formerly incapable person continues the proceedings, they become potentially liable for the costs of the whole of the proceedings, including those incurred during the period of disability: Bligh v Tredgett (1851) 5 De G & SM 74; 64 ER 1024; New South Wales Insurance Ministerial Corp v Abualfoul (1999) 94 FCR 247; 162 ALR 417; [1999] FCA 433; BC9901640 . In some mental illnesses, a person’s capacity fluctuates. In the context of litigation it is unsatisfactory to be appointing and removing tutors as a condition fluctuates. Accordingly in such a case if there is a significant risk that at times during the conduct of the litigation the client will be relevantly incapacitated, semble that would justify the appointment of a tutor for the whole of the litigation: see the Hon Justice PLG Brereton “Acting for the Incapable — A Delicate Balance” (2012) 35 Australian Bar Review 244 at 246–247.

The provisions of the present rule are simply machinery or procedural provisions designed primarily to ensure that there is someone answerable to the court on behalf of the litigant with a disability. Those provisions do not affect the accrual or suspension of a cause of action possessed by an incapable person: State Rail Authority of New South Wales v Hammond (1988) 15 NSWLR 395 at 401 .

level.toc-caption: [7.14.30] Next friend, guardian ad litem, tutor

heading.title: Next friend, guardian ad litem, tutor

p.text: Historically, a guardian ad litem was either appointed by the court for the particular suit or by the King's letters patent — and in that case had a general power to conduct litigation. Where the guardian was appointed by the court, the infant was required to attend personally when the appointment was made. The office of next friend or “prochein ami” was the product of the Statute of Westminster the First (1275) (UK) and the Statute of Westminster the Second (1285) (UK). By the former statute, the next friend was authorised to take proceedings on behalf of an infant who was unable to attend, or prevented from attending, the assizes. Under the Statute of Westminster the Second, the next friend was permitted to sue in all actions. These historical references are now replaced by the single term “tutor”.

level.toc-caption: [7.14.35] Tutor to carry on proceedings without a solicitor

p.text: Legislation cited in [7.14.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Mental Health Act 2007 s 71.

heading.title: Tutor to carry on proceedings without a solicitor

p.text: For an example of the court allowing a tutor to carry on proceedings without a solicitor see A bht Collins v Mental Health Review Tribunal [2010] NSWSC 1363; BC201008927 (primary carer for the purposes of s 71 Mental Health Act 2007 permitted to carry on proceedings without a solicitor — satisfied that the interests of the plaintiff would be appropriately protected); see also [7.15.40] . However, these kinds of examples depend on the particular circumstances, including the nature of the proceedings and the personal qualities and abilities of the tutor. The more general position is that only qualified practitioners should represent parties, and that it is undesirable for leave to be granted to permit the proceedings to be conducted by unqualified representatives: see further [7.1.5] ; Wang v NSW [2011] NSWSC 609; BC201104491 (a husband was refused leave to represent his incapacitated wife — the claim raised difficult legal issues and there was inadequate evidence of the tutor’s inability to obtain appropriate legal representation).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.15] r 7.15 Tutors generally (cf SCR Part 63, rules 4 and 5; DCR Part 45, rules 4 and 5; LCR Part 34, rules 5 and 6)

leg:heading.title: Tutors generally (cf SCR Part 63, rules 4 and 5; DCR Part 45, rules 4 and 5; LCR Part 34, rules 5 and 6)

p.text: Subject to this Division, a person may become the tutor of a person under legal incapacity without the need for any formal instrument of appointment or any order of a court.
Any person (other than a corporation) is eligible to be the tutor of a person under legal incapacity, in respect of any proceedings, unless the person is:
a person under legal incapacity, or
a judicial officer, a registrar or any other person involved in the administration of a court, or
a person who has an interest in the proceedings adverse to the interests of the person under legal incapacity.

In the case of proceedings with respect to the estate of a person whose estate is subject to management under the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 , the tutor of that person is to be the person who has the management of the person’s estate under that Act.
[subr (3) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[5], effective 8 October 2009]
Subrule (3) does not apply if the person concerned declines to act as tutor or is unable to act as tutor, or if the court orders otherwise.
A person may not replace another person as tutor of a person under legal incapacity except by order of the court.

Anything that these rules authorise or require a party to do in relation to the conduct of proceedings may, if the party is a person under legal incapacity, be done on his or her behalf by his or her tutor.
Legislation cited in [7.15.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.16.

An order is only required where it is sought to substitute one tutor for another or where it is sought to substitute a tutor for the curator of an incompetent person or where an incapable person fails to appear. Even if no formal order of appointment is necessary, a tutor may not take any step in the proceedings until r 7.16 has been complied with.

A person within the jurisdiction, not being under a personal incapacity to sue, not being an accounting party, not having an interest adverse to the disabled person and not connected with any other party may be a tutor: R v Registrar of Melbourne County Court [1927] VLR 406 . If a tutor is resident out of the jurisdiction, he or she may be required to provide security for costs: Didisheim v London and Westminster Bank [1900] 2 Ch 15 at 43 . A tutor should be a substantial person and it is desirable that they should be a relation or friend of the family and not a mere volunteer. A parent is preferred (Woolf v Pemberton (1877) 6 Ch D 19 ; cited in Dey v Victorian Railway Cmrs (1949) 78 CLR 62 at 113; [1949] ALR 333; BC4900050 ), but in their absence a guardian may act as tutor: Hutchinson v Norwood (1885) 31 Ch D 237 . The defendant or mere nominee of the defendant cannot be tutor (Re Burgess (1883) 25 Ch D 243 ; Lewis v Nobbs (1878) 8 Ch D 591 ), nor can an infant (Fernee v Gorlitz [1915] 1 Ch 177 ), nor can a company (Re Stewart (1893) 5 QLJ 81 ). A solicitor may be a tutor: Lawrence v Moyes (1900) 16 WN (NSW) 229 ; Loorham v Loorham (1947) 65 WN (NSW) 98 ; Ex parte Shearer [1949] QWN 41 . If the incapable person has no relative or friend who consents to act, an independent solicitor will be an appropriate person to appoint as tutor: Lawrence v Moyes (1900) 16 WN (NSW) 229 ; Sanguinetti v Weaver (1910) 27 WN (NSW) 142 ; Deputy Cmr of Taxation v P (1987) 11 NSWLR 200 . A solicitor so appointed may also act as the solicitor on the record: Deputy Cmr of Taxation v P, above; Eady v Elsdon [1901] 2 KB 460 ; Re PC [1961] Ch 312 ; cf Loorham v Loorham (1947) 65 WN (NSW) 98 .

Where the issue of capacity is contentious, and opposed by the person concerned, it is generally undesirable for the person’s solicitor to seek appointment as the tutor: McD v McD [1983] 3 NSWLR 81 at 84C (an application for the appointment the Protective Commissioner to manage the plaintiff’s affairs); R v P (2001) 53 NSWLR 664 at 683; [2001] NSWCA 473; BC20010780 at [64] per Hodgson JA. But in exceptional cases (for example where family member nor friend, nor even one of the trustee companies is available or willing to make such an application, the person’s solicitor might be appointed to act as tutor. In such a case the solicitor will have to balance conflicting duties to the client and to the court: see the Hon Justice PLG Brereton “Acting for the Incapable — A Delicate Balance” (2012) 35 Australian Bar Review 244 at 247–249.

level.toc-caption: [7.15.12] Who may be a tutor — person under management

p.text: Legislation cited in [7.15.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 s 41.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.15(3)–(5).

heading.title: Who may be a tutor — person under management

p.text: If a person has a manager of their estate, as a result of an appointment under s 41 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, the manager should be their tutor in the proceedings. If the manager does not agree to act as the tutor the court may appoint a different tutor: UCPR r 7.15(3)–(5) . If the management order is contentious (because of a pending appeal and doubt about whether the person is incapable of managing their affairs) the Supreme Court has an inherent power, in the exercise of its protective jurisdiction, to appoint a tutor. That appointment may be made retrospective to the commencement of the proceedings: Bobolas v Waverley Council (2012) 187 LGERA 63; [2012] NSWCA 126; BC201202857 at [58]–[62], per McColl JA citing Re P [2006] NSWSC 1082; BC200608224 at [8] per Young CJ in Eq, Macfarlan JA & Tobias AJA agreeing (manager declined to act, daughter appointed).

A change of tutor can only be effected by order. A person who is a tutor in any proceedings is entitled and indeed bound to continue to act as tutor unless and until the court substitutes another person to act in that capacity. Generally, a tutor cannot retire without giving security for costs incurred: Davenport v Davenport (1822) 1 Sim & St 101; 57 ER 40, but a replacement tutor is liable for the whole costs of the proceedings and not just those incurred after their appointment: Bligh v Tredgett (1851) 5 De G & SM 74; 64 ER 1024. A tutor may be removed by the court on the grounds of either actual impropriety or conflict of interest: Stephenson v Geiss [1998] 1 Qd R 542 at 557; BC9702989 .

level.toc-caption: [7.15.20] Status and function of the tutor

heading.title: Status and function of the tutor

p.text: The tutor is not a party to the action and can only be interrogated about the disabled person's knowledge as distinct from the tutor's personal knowledge: Pink v JA Sharwood and Co Ltd [1913] 2 Ch 286 ; Jackson v Roberts (1941) ALR (CN) 365. Nor can the tutor be required to provide personal discovery: Dyke v Stephens (1885) 30 Ch D 190 at 190. There is some dispute as to whether the purpose of a tutor is simply to provide for the defendant's costs: Ex parte Davis (1901) 1 SR (NSW) 187 ; Catt v Wood [1908] 2 KB 458 at 473 ; Darke v Eltherington [1963] Qd R 375 at 385 , or whether it carries a wider responsibility to safeguard the interests of the plaintiff in connection with the proceedings: R v Registrar of Melbourne County Court [1927] VLR 406 ; Dey v Victorian Railway Cmrs (1949) 78 CLR 62 at 83, 113; [1949] ALR 333; BC4900050 ; Rhodes v Swithenbank (1889) 22 QBD 577 at 578 (tutor cannot compromise without court approval).
Legislation cited in [7.15.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 75 and 76.

A tutor is not the general guardian of the disabled person: Re Marquis of Salisbury (1876) 2 Ch D 29 . However, the tutor can consent to any necessary procedural directions for the conduct of the proceedings: Knatchbull v Fowle (1876) 1 Ch D 604 (consents to the hearing of the proceedings by affidavit instead of by oral evidence); Fryer v Wiseman (1876) 45 LJ Ch 199; Piggott v Toogood [1904] WN 130. However, the tutor is not a party to the proceedings: Pink v JA Sharwood and Co Ltd [1913] 2 Ch 286 at 289 ; and the tutor is not entitled to be heard in person: Murray v Sitwell [1902] WN (Eng) 119; Re Berry [1903] WN (Eng) 125. The tutor's power to compromise proceedings is limited to a compromise for the benefit of the disabled person: Rhodes v Swithenbank (1889) 22 QBD 577 ; and approval to the compromise must be obtained under CPA ss 75 and 76 . The court will not enforce a compromise against the opinion of the tutor and his advisers: Re Birchall (1880) 16 Ch D 41 .

Any adverse costs orders will usually be made against the person who sues or defends by a tutor. But a tutor is, in reality, a party to the proceedings: Yakmor v Hamdoush (No 2) (2009) 76 NSWLR 148; [2009] NSWCA 284; BC200909126 at [24], [44], [45] (tutor to pay the costs of the appeal); and costs orders can be made directly against a tutor: Nadile v Protective Commissioner (NSWSC, Young J, 5557 of 1992, 6 October 1993, unreported, BC9302154); O’Brien v O’Brien (1995) 35 NSWLR 664 at 667; 21 MVR 106 (order that next friend pay the costs of a motion in the District Court); Fisher v Marin [2008] NSWSC 1357; BC200811207 (order directly against tutor contemplated). In any event, a tutor is personally liable for any costs orders made against the incapable person: Buckly v Buckeridge (1767) 1 Dick 395; 21 ER 323 ; Radford v Cavanagh (1899) 15 WN (NSW) 226a ; Catt v Wood [1908] 2 KB 458 at 473 ; Re An Incapable Person D [1983] 2 NSWLR 590; (1983) 74 FLR 413 (Protective Commissioner appointed as tutor of an incapable person); Spina v Permanent Custodians Ltd (2009) 14 BPR 26,293; [2009] NSWCA 206; BC200906292 at [147] . The tutor will also be liable, as a general rule, to pay the incapable person's own solicitor's bill of costs: Re Flower (1871) 19 WR 578; Hawkes v Cottrell (1858) 27 LJ Ex 369. The tutor's liability continues until the incapacity ceases: Bligh v Tredgett (1851) 5 De G & SM 74; 64 ER 1024.

Tutor’s indemnity: The tutor is entitled to an indemnity in respect of all costs properly incurred: Murray v Kirkpatrick (1940) 57 WN (NSW) 162 ; Pritchard v Roberts (1873) LR17Eq 222 . Properly incurred costs do not include costs incurred in proceedings brought for the tutor's own purposes, or to harass the defendants, rather than for the benefit of the incapable person: Walker v Else (1835) 4 LJ Ch 54; Sale v Sale (1839) 1 Beav 586; 48 ER 1068 ; Parlebean v Wickham (1848) 11 LTOS 44. Similarly, full indemnity does not extend to include additional costs incurred as a consequence of having brought proceedings in an inappropriate court: Chapman v Freeman [1962] VR 259 ; Thatcher v Scott [1968] 1 NSWR 556; (1968) 87 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 461 (Supreme Court proceedings that could have been conducted in the District Court).

level.toc-caption: [7.15.35] Payment of judgment or compromise amount

p.text: Legislation cited in [7.15.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 77(2) and (3).

heading.title: Payment of judgment or compromise amount

p.text: Payment should be made by paying the money into court or to such other person as the court directs: see CPA s 77(2) and (3) . Where the plaintiff has been represented by a tutor, the court must be satisfied that payment to the plaintiff is appropriate, either on an application to discharge the tutor, or on the basis that the plaintiff is capable of managing his or her affairs. The fact that the Guardianship Board has dismissed an application for the appointment of a manager does not prevent the court satisfying itself that payment to the plaintiff is appropriate: Lim v Nominal Defendant (NSWSC, Hodgson J, 27 June 1997, unreported, BC9702918).
Legislation cited in [7.15.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.14.

Where the appointed tutor is a solicitor, it may be appropriate to dispense with the requirement in r 7.14 of the UCPR that the tutor must act by a solicitor: Deputy Cmr of Taxation v P (1987) 11 NSWLR 200 ; Schwartz Family Co Pty Ltd v Bentwood [2002] NSWSC 1020; BC200206433 .

Where a party is subject to management under the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, the tutor of that person is to be the manager of the person's estate under that Act, or if the manager declines to act or is unable to act as tutor, the Court may make an order for appointment of a tutor: UCPR 7.15(3)–(5). If the management order is being appealed or contested or if there may be doubt as to whether a person's mental state falls within the statutory definition of "person under legal incapacity" the Court has inherent power to appoint a tutor under its parens patriae jurisdiction and for that order to operate nunc pro tunc: Bobolas v Waverley Council (2012) 187 LGERA 63; [2012] NSWCA 126; BC201202857 , per McColl JA at [58]–[62] citing Re P [2006] NSWSC 1082; BC200608224 per Young CJ in Eq at [8], Macfarlan JA & Tobias AJA agreeing (manager declined to act, daughter appointed).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.16] r 7.16 Tutor to file certain documents (cf SCR Part 63, rule 4; DCR Part 45, rule 4; LCR Part 34, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Tutor to file certain documents (cf SCR Part 63, rule 4; DCR Part 45, rule 4; LCR Part 34, rule 5)

p.text: A tutor may not commence or carry on proceedings on behalf of a person under legal incapacity unless there have been filed:
the tutor’s consent to act as tutor, and

a certificate, signed by the tutor’s solicitor in the proceedings, to the effect that the tutor does not have any interest in the proceedings adverse to the interests of the person under legal incapacity.
The approved form is Form 30 : Consent to act as tutor.
Legislation cited in [7.16.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.15.

The consent should be executed in accordance with r 31.15 . The omission to file the written consent is an irregularity only and cannot be taken advantage of by the defendant: Re Wilson (1904) 21 WN (NSW) 98 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.17] r 7.17 Non-appearance of person under legal incapacity (cf SCR Part 63, rule 6; DCR Part 45, rule 6; LCR Part 34, rules 3A and 7)

leg:heading.title: Non-appearance of person under legal incapacity (cf SCR Part 63, rule 6; DCR Part 45, rule 6; LCR Part 34, rules 3A and 7)

p.text: Subject to subrule (2), the plaintiff in proceedings against a defendant who is a person under legal incapacity may take no further step in the proceedings following service of the originating process until a tutor has entered an appearance on behalf of the defendant.
If no such appearance is entered, the plaintiff may apply to the court under rule 7.18 for the appointment of a tutor of the defendant, or for the removal and appointment of such a tutor.
In the case of proceedings in the Local Court against a defendant who appears to be a person under legal incapacity by reason only of his or her minority:
the plaintiff may serve on the defendant a notice requiring a tutor of the defendant to enter an appearance in the proceedings, and

unless the court orders otherwise, the plaintiff may continue the proceedings as if the defendant were not a person under legal incapacity if such an appearance is not entered within 28 days after service of the notice.
[subr (2) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]

No proceedings in default of appearance can be taken against an incapable person unless and until a tutor has been appointed and any such proceedings are irregular by reason of non-compliance with the requirements of the rule, whether the plaintiff knew of the disability or not. Non-compliance does not, however, render the proceedings void: John v John [1965] P 289.

A plaintiff may nominate an appropriate person to be appointed by the court as tutor for an incapable prospective defendant. The plaintiff must make a similar application where the defendant becomes an incompetent person after the defendant has entered an appearance: Michaletos v Stivactas [1992] ANZ ConvR 90; (1991) NSW ConvR 55-590; BC9101807 . An independent solicitor is likely to be an appropriate person. The consent of the solicitor should be obtained prior to the seeking of the appointment as the court will not impose the significant responsibilities and duties of a tutor on an officer of the court without his consent: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v P (1987) 11 NSWLR 200 . See also [7.18.3] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.18] r 7.18 Court may appoint and remove tutors (cf SCR Part 63, rules 5, 7 and 8; DCR Part 45, rules 7 and 8; LCR Part 34, rules 8 and 9)

leg:heading.title: Court may appoint and remove tutors (cf SCR Part 63, rules 5, 7 and 8; DCR Part 45, rules 7 and 8; LCR Part 34, rules 8 and 9)

p.text: In any proceedings in which a party is or becomes a person under legal incapacity:
if the person does not have a tutor, the court may appoint a tutor, or
if the person has a tutor, the court may remove the party’s tutor and appoint another tutor.
In any proceedings concerning a person under legal incapacity who is not a party, the court may appoint a tutor of the person and join the person as a party to the proceedings.
If the court removes a party’s tutor, it may also stay the proceedings pending the appointment of a new tutor.
Subject to any order of the court, notice of any motion under this rule is to be served on the person under legal incapacity and, if it proposes removal of the person’s tutor, on the tutor.
In proceedings on a motion for the appointment of a tutor, evidence in support of the motion must include:
evidence that the party for whom a tutor is to be appointed is a person under legal incapacity, and
evidence that the proposed tutor consents to being appointed and does not have any interest in the proceedings adverse to the interests of the person under legal incapacity.
An application for appointment as tutor under this rule may be made by the court of its own motion or on the motion of any other person, including the proposed tutor.
Legislation cited in [7.18.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.18(1), r 7.18(5), r 7.36.

Each court to which the present rule applies has the power to appoint a tutor in relation to proceedings in the court where the person concerned is “a person under a legal incapacity” within the meaning of CPA s 3: Re P [2006] NSWSC 1082; BC200608224 at [2] (District Court judge has power to appoint a tutor). The Supreme Court has power under its parens patriae jurisdiction and semble under UCPR r 7.18(1) to appoint a tutor even though the proceedings are in another court: R v NSW Trustee and Guardian [2010] NSWSC 1154; BC201007701 at [8]–[10] per Palmer J (tutor appointed for District Court proceedings).

The Supreme Court, in the exercise of its protective jurisdiction, may have an inherent power to appoint a tutor even if a person does not fall within the definition of “person under a legal incapacity” for the purposes of CPA s 3 and UCPR r 7.18 does not apply: Re P [2006] NSWSC 1082; BC200608224 at [5] and [8] (temporary mental illness — litigant unable to give meaningful instructions — tutor appointed); Re SK [2005] 2 FCR(UK) 459; [2005] 3 All ER 421; [2006] 1 WLR 81; [2004] EWHC 3202 (Fam) (persons kidnapped for the purpose of arranged marriages outside the jurisdiction).

Subject to exceptional circumstances, the power to appoint a tutor is limited to situations of actual cognitive disability. It does not apply where the evidence is limited to difficulties of language or physical health: HSBC Bank Australia Ltd v Chang [2007] NSWSC 1127; BC200708732 .

The appointment may be conditional, subject to the provision of the necessary evidence under UCPR r 7.18(5) : Porter v Phong Le [2010] NSWSC 998; BC201006588 at [6], [13] (new tutor appointed subject to evidence that she has no interest in the proceedings adverse to the interests of the incapable person).

The decision to appoint a tutor should take into account the represented person’s interests and means. If the person lacks the ability to find an appropriate tutor, or the means to meet their expenses, it is likely to be desirable for the court to invite the Law Society or the Bar Association to provide assistance: see discussion Iskander v Mahbur [2011] NSWSC 1056; BC201106956 at [16] and following, see also UCPR r 7.36 .

A tutor may be removed if they have an interest in the suit adverse to the incapable person; if they are closely connected with another party who has an adverse interest; if they will not proceed with the action; if they conduct it improperly; or if there is some more suitable party: Re Birchall (1880) 16 Ch D 41 ; Woolf v Pemberton (1877) 6 Ch D 19 ; Hutchinson v Norwood (1885) 31 Ch D 237 ; R v Registrar of Melbourne County Court [1927] VLR 406 and see Daniell's Chancery Practice, 7th ed, 1901, p 121. If a compromise is for the benefit of an infant but the tutor refuses to consent thereto, they may be removed: Re Birchall , above. A long checklist of considerations on an application to remove a manager or the NSW Trustee (previously the Protective Commissioner) under s 22 of the Protected Estates Act 1983 (repealed, see now NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 ss 41 , 52 ) was given in Holt v Protective Cmr (1993) 31 NSWLR 227 . Some of those considerations may be relevant to an application under this rule. Conflict or misconduct necessitating the removal of the tutor will rarely justify an order dispensing with the requirement for a tutor, even if no substitute is proffered who is willing to accept potential liability for the costs of the proceedings: South v Northern Sydney Area Health Service [2003] NSWSC 479; BC200302911 (parent conflicted, Protective Commissioner unwilling to accept appointment as tutor).
